items.body_markdown:
I'm a novice at Android Development and I've written a Wyse60 Emulator for Android but it bogs down and freezes after a minute. It's basically a modified a Bluetooth chat program - it has a separate thread for monitoring the Bluetooth port and putting the messages in a broadcaster. The main thread receives the messages, decodes it, and sets the TextView. I must have something designed incorrectly because I get "The application may be doing too much work on its main thread." 

The decoding is based on [this monstrosity](https://code.google.com/archive/p/wy60/), updates an ArrayList of SpannableStringBuilder before concatenating them all as a master SpannableStringBuilder to write to the TextView.

For those that don't know, Wyse60 messages are of the form:
```
Goto [X, Y]
set [attributes]
write [characters]
```

And, for a screen 80 characters wide 42 lines high, there are a lot of them. Plus, the host pings the terminal every second.

Is there a better way to approach this? 
Should I use MVVM/LiveData? 
Is my testing device too old (Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge)?

I've looked for sections algorithmically expensive and ideas to separate the decoding to a separate thread. I can find neither.

I will work on converting to MVVM/LiveData, but I don't think it will help. Currently using LocalBroadCastManager.

Thanks.

answers.body_markdown:
A more plausible explanation is that the connection object is used by more than one thread concurrently, and the other thread has changed the auto-commit mode between your two getAutoCommit() calls. It is strongly recommended to not concurrently share a JDBC connection across threads for various reasons, one of which is the behavior you're seeing, but you could also end up dead-locking your database session.

The JDBC spec states that the calling commit() on a connection that has auto-commit mode enabled should throw an exception. But there is a JDBC property that can be used to relax this behavior: set "oracle.jdbc.autoCommitSpecCompliant" to "false". See the Javadoc [here][1].


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/jajdb/oracle/jdbc/OracleConnection.html#CONNECTION_PROPERTY_AUTO_COMMIT_SPEC_COMPLIANT
answers.title: JDBC with Oracle - executeUpdate automatically changes status of AutoCommit
answers.body:
A more plausible explanation is that the connection object is used by more than one thread concurrently, and the other thread has changed the auto-commit mode between your two getAutoCommit() calls. It is strongly recommended to not concurrently share a JDBC connection across threads for various reasons, one of which is the behavior you're seeing, but you could also end up dead-locking your database session.

The JDBC spec states that the calling commit() on a connection that has auto-commit mode enabled should throw an exception. But there is a JDBC property that can be used to relax this behavior: set "oracle.jdbc.autoCommitSpecCompliant" to "false". See the Javadoc here.

items.body_markdown:
We have a Java application that uses connection pooling. Usuallay at the start of each function/process we use `setAutoCommit(false);` to switch off AutoCommit. And in the finally section, after commit/rollback we switch it back to ON using `setAutoCommit(true);` 

From time to time we were getting this Exception in a few functions:

    java.sql.SQLException: Could not commit with auto-commit set on

Upon investigation we found that **randomly** the AutoCommit status changes from OFF/false to ON/true after `executeUpdate` without any apparent reason.

    status = connection.getAutoCommit(); // stores false
    statement.executeUpdate(sQuery.toString());
    status = connection.getAutoCommit(); // stores true

As I said it doesn't always happen. There is no other function call between these lines that could possibly change the status.

As a workaround we have restored the AutoCommit status after executeUpdate if it changes. But we need to know more as executeUpdate is used a few dozen time in the application.

Has anyone faced similar issue? Any solution other than the above?

We are using Java 1.8 with Oracle 11 and ojdbc8-19.3.0.0.jar
items.title: JDBC with Oracle - executeUpdate automatically changes status of AutoCommit
items.body:
We have a Java application that uses connection pooling. Usuallay at the start of each function/process we use setAutoCommit(false); to switch off AutoCommit. And in the finally section, after commit/rollback we switch it back to ON using setAutoCommit(true);

From time to time we were getting this Exception in a few functions:

java.sql.SQLException: Could not commit with auto-commit set on

Upon investigation we found that randomly the AutoCommit status changes from OFF/false to ON/true after executeUpdate without any apparent reason.

status = connection.getAutoCommit(); // stores false
statement.executeUpdate(sQuery.toString());
status = connection.getAutoCommit(); // stores true

As I said it doesn't always happen. There is no other function call between these lines that could possibly change the status.

As a workaround we have restored the AutoCommit status after executeUpdate if it changes. But we need to know more as executeUpdate is used a few dozen time in the application.

Has anyone faced similar issue? Any solution other than the above?

We are using Java 1.8 with Oracle 11 and ojdbc8-19.3.0.0.jar

answers.body_markdown:
You can use the [`plus`][1] method of `DayOfWeek`. 

>The calculation rolls around the end of the week from Sunday to Monday.

Increment numbers with [`IntStream`][2] and its [`range`][3] method (*inclusive* start, *exclusive* end). 

    Locale locale = Locale.CANADA_FRENCH;
    DayOfWeek firstDayOfWeek = WeekFields.of(locale).getFirstDayOfWeek();

    List<DayOfWeek> dows = IntStream.range(0, 7)
            .mapToObj(firstDayOfWeek::plus)
            .collect(Collectors.toList());


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/java/time/DayOfWeek.html#plus-long-
  [2]: https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/util/stream/IntStream.html
  [3]: https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/util/stream/IntStream.html#range(int,int)
answers.title: List<DayOfWeek> in localized order
answers.body:
You can use the plus method of DayOfWeek.

The calculation rolls around the end of the week from Sunday to Monday.

Increment numbers with IntStream and its range method (inclusive start, exclusive end). 

Locale locale = Locale.CANADA_FRENCH;
DayOfWeek firstDayOfWeek = WeekFields.of(locale).getFirstDayOfWeek();

List<DayOfWeek> dows = IntStream.range(0, 7)
        .mapToObj(firstDayOfWeek::plus)
        .collect(Collectors.toList());

answers.title: List<DayOfWeek> in localized order
answers.body:
My solution in Kotlin:

fun sortedDaysOfWeek(locale: Locale = Locale.getDefault()): List<DayOfWeek> {
     val firstDayOfWeek = WeekFields.of(locale).firstDayOfWeek

     return DayOfWeek.values().partition { it == firstDayOfWeek }
                              .let{ it.first + it.second }
}

comments.body_markdown: This is transient state that seems very specific to the parent->child relationship. What do you want to happen with that state when child is loaded without its parent, or from some other relationship? That said, I'd do it yourself in the object model by instrumenting the parent.getChild() call so that you update the child instance with the parent data before returning it. It will work the same regardless of the child being eager or lazy loaded

answers.body_markdown:
IntelliJ offers a way to set the profile for spring boot app in the run configuration. See below "Active profiles". You can still add environment variable `SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=local`
[![setting profile][1]][1]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/Vtzss.png
answers.title: Setting Springboot profiles on intellij Idea 2022.* community edition
answers.body: IntelliJ offers a way to set the profile for spring boot app in the run configuration. See below "Active profiles". You can still add environment variable SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=local

answers.body_markdown:
In the newer version of Springboot (2.7.0+) The `application.properties` is selected by default regardless of what VM option is selected.

- We should have environment specific `application.properties`. For example `application-local.properties`
- Create an empty `application.properties` file.
- With this setup spring will select the right `application-{env}.properties` file.

Note: You still need to have the VM argument in the run configurations `-Dspring.profiles.active={env}`
answers.title: Setting Springboot profiles on intellij Idea 2022.* community edition
answers.body:
In the newer version of Springboot (2.7.0+) The application.properties is selected by default regardless of what VM option is selected.

  • We should have environment specific application.properties. For example application-local.properties
  • Create an empty application.properties file.
  • With this setup spring will select the right application-{env}.properties file.

Note: You still need to have the VM argument in the run configurations -Dspring.profiles.active={env}

answers.title: Get names of firebase database nodes without getting their values and store them as list in Android studio

But your code can process the result to only use the keys:

databaseReference.child("users").child("students").addValueEventListener(new ValueEventListener() {
    @Override

        for (DataSnapshot dataSnapshot : snapshot.getChildren()) {
            Log.i("Firebase", dataSnapshot.getKey());
        }

        ...
    }

answers.title: Why try-with-resources causes Truncated chunk error with CloseableHttpClient?
answers.body:
The try-with-resources block will automatically call close() on the object, so the return from one of those getRequest calls is a closed CloseableHttpClient instance.

The call without try-with-resources will return a working (not closed) CloseableHttpClient. Put a really clear comment on the version which does not auto-close:

/**
  * http get request (create get connection with particular url)
  * @return open CloseableHttpResponse connection, caller must close after use.
  */
public static CloseableHttpResponse getRequest(String url) throws IOException {
    CloseableHttpClient httpClient = HttpClients.createDefault();
    HttpGet httpget = new HttpGet(url);
    return httpClient.execute(httpget);
}

The callers need to handle close explicitly after use, or via try-with-resources like this:

try(CloseableHttpResponse response = getRequest(url)) {
    // Process response
}

answers.title: create Bean in Spring through AsyncConfigurerSupport, respecting best practices with constructor
answers.body:
It can be done through ApplicationContext in this way.

package com.my.spring.app.config;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Bean;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;
import org.springframework.scheduling.annotation.AsyncConfigurerSupport;
import org.springframework.scheduling.annotation.EnableAsync;

@Configuration
@EnableAsync
public class SpringConfig extends AsyncConfigurerSupport {
  private final ApplicationContext context;

  @Autowired
  public SpringConfig(ApplicationContext context) {
    this.context = context;
  }

  @Bean
  public AsyncSendingService asyncSendingService() {
    return context.getBean(AsyncSendingServiceImpl.class);
  }
}

comments.body_markdown: Kotlin now requires a JVM target >= 1.8 (i.e. Java 8). Anything lower than that will result in a deprecation warning: `JVM target 1.6 is deprecated and will be removed in a future release. Please migrate to JVM target 1.8 or above`
comments.body: Kotlin now requires a JVM target >= 1.8 (i.e. Java 8). Anything lower than that will result in a deprecation warning: JVM target 1.6 is deprecated and will be removed in a future release. Please migrate to JVM target 1.8 or above

answers.body_markdown:
Yes, the JDK is required for Kotlin development on the JVM.

Historically, Kotlin worked with JDK 1.6+ targets. Starting with [Kotlin 1.5](https://kotlinlang.org/docs/whatsnew15.html#new-default-jvm-target-1-8), Kotlin needs a JDK with version 1.8 (i.e. Java 8) or higher.
answers.title: Is the JDK required for Kotlin?
answers.body:
Yes, the JDK is required for Kotlin development on the JVM.

Historically, Kotlin worked with JDK 1.6+ targets. Starting with Kotlin 1.5, Kotlin needs a JDK with version 1.8 (i.e. Java 8) or higher.

comments.body_markdown: Or more broadly, Kotlin was added to the list of languages that are supported to use the JVM, along with Groovy, Scala, and Clojure. Kotlin just happens to have first class support in Android
comments.body: Or more broadly, Kotlin was added to the list of languages that are supported to use the JVM, along with Groovy, Scala, and Clojure. Kotlin just happens to have first class support in Android

answers.body_markdown:
Yes! Kotlin 1.1.2 (and above) require JDK.

Also, very importantly, **Kotlin wasn't supposed so as to "replace" Java**. This is another very common erroneous notion. Kotlin was merely added to the list of languages supported for writing Android apps.

You can check out the link below to get a feel of the language's history:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kotlin_(programming_language)

answers.body:
Yes! Kotlin 1.1.2 (and above) require JDK.

Also, very importantly, Kotlin wasn't supposed so as to "replace" Java. This is another very common erroneous notion. Kotlin was merely added to the list of languages supported for writing Android apps.

answers.body_markdown:
As already mentioned, Kotlin JVM requires the JVM to work. Kotlin compiles to JVM bytecode, which means it has the same requirements as Java (runtime and development kit). This is also why Kotlin has Java interop. Additionally, this is the one you're most likely to find yourself using with Android. 

However, there is [Kotlin Native](https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-native/). The SDK itself is slightly different from Kotlin JVM, and it's still a WIP, but it compiles without the need for JVM. Specifically, it compiles to a native target using LLVM. This version of Kotlin supports C interop.

Kotlin Native also opens the door for [Kotlin Multiplatform](https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/multiplatform.html), which compiles to whatever you want (mobile targets, desktop targets, and it packs it all into one, and includes interop with the native programming language). **NOTE:** I'm not sure what Kotlin Native with Multiplatform compiles to. Some demo projects use Kotlin JVM in the Android module, which suggests it doesn't use NDK-style native code. Multiplatforms, like Native, is experimental. I also haven't touched Multiplatform much, but it appears to be using a combination of declared functions and platform-declared functions. I'm not sure how interop works here (in terms of languages - not module interop). 

Multiplatform doesn't require Native though, but it enables significantly more platforms. If you're using a cross-platform Java library (for an instance LibGDX), or otherwise build on modules with a core and platforms, you can use Multiplatform here too. However, note that this likely requires the JDK, although it does depend on your project.

In addition to these, there's also [Kotlin.JS](https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/js-overview.html), which as the name suggests, compiles to JavaScript. Unlike Kotlin JVM, it naturally doesn't require the JVM. However, it instead requires the JavaScript-related APIs. And as you'd expect, Kotlin.JS supports JavaScript interop. 

**TL;DR:**

The JDK isn't always required. Kotlin Native and Kotlin JS do not require the JDK, because the targets they compile to isn't on the JVM.

However, there is Kotlin Native. The SDK itself is slightly different from Kotlin JVM, and it's still a WIP, but it compiles without the need for JVM. Specifically, it compiles to a native target using LLVM. This version of Kotlin supports C interop.

Kotlin Native also opens the door for Kotlin Multiplatform, which compiles to whatever you want (mobile targets, desktop targets, and it packs it all into one, and includes interop with the native programming language). NOTE: I'm not sure what Kotlin Native with Multiplatform compiles to. Some demo projects use Kotlin JVM in the Android module, which suggests it doesn't use NDK-style native code. Multiplatforms, like Native, is experimental. I also haven't touched Multiplatform much, but it appears to be using a combination of declared functions and platform-declared functions. I'm not sure how interop works here (in terms of languages - not module interop).

Multiplatform doesn't require Native though, but it enables significantly more platforms. If you're using a cross-platform Java library (for an instance LibGDX), or otherwise build on modules with a core and platforms, you can use Multiplatform here too. items.body_markdown:
I have created an AWS Lambda Function URL which on a scheduled base (every 5mins) sends RESTful messages to another API endpoint (managed internally by our company). The Lambda Function sends light payload to the external API which sets up some background processing and respond with an acknowledgement in the response immediately. The same Lambda Function then also listens for update notifications from the background process. The API processing is not expensive, normally it would respond within 100ms. However; there are times when the outbound connections to the external API simply times out (timeout set to 30s) and the AWS Lambda is "stuck" in this state for hours until some magic happens and the AWS Lambda can send requests again. The inbound requests (update notifications) are continuing to be accepted by the Lambda Function without issues. The last successful batch were 35 requests in about 2hours, after which the timeout occurred again. I have tried sending these outbound messages to another known endpoint and get the same timeout when it happens.
The Lambda Function URL is configured with VPC which is the same subnet as the external API endpoint. The Lambda code is deployed as a container image via CI/CD.

I have tried creating another Lambda Function URL with logic closely mimicking the prod version, minus some details (no RDS, no VPC, packaged using Maven and uploaded through Amazon Dashboard) and deployed. This test Lambda is targeting the same API endpoint as in prod and I get no timeout whatsoever running it for a day. So the only difference is the VPC configuration and the code being deployed.
I have also tried both HttpUrlConnection and java.net.http.HttpClient clients to see if they behave differently but both are timing out in the end.

I suspect this may be VPC related but has anyone experienced such intermittent issues?

@EnableWebSecurity

    @Order(1)
    public SecurityFilterChain restFilterChain(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
        return http
                .cors().and().csrf().disable()
                .authorizeRequests().antMatchers("/api/login").anonymous().and()
                .authorizeRequests().antMatchers("/api/**").authenticated().and()
                .sessionManagement().sessionCreationPolicy(SessionCreationPolicy.STATELESS).and()
                .addFilterBefore(authTokenFilter(), UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter.class)
                .build();
    }

    @Bean
    @Order(2)

items.title: Grouping class object constants
items.body:
I have a group of class object constants defined in a class like so:

public static class ClassConstants {
    public static final Class<ClassModel1> CLASS1 = ClassModel1.class;
    public static final Class<ClassModel2> CLASS2 = ClassModel2.class;
    public static final Class<ClassModel3> CLASS3 = ClassModel3.class;
}

This works, but since it is horrendously ugly and not type-safe, I would like to convert it into an enum. I can't seem to get the syntax right, though. So far, I have:

public enum ClassConstantsEnum {
    CLASS1(Class1.class),
    CLASS2(Class2.class),
    CLASS3(Class3.class);

    private final Class<? extends ClassModelBase> clazz;
    <T extends ClassModelBase> ClassConstantsEnum(Class<T> clazz) { this.clazz = clazz; }
    public Class<? extends ClassModelBase> get() { return this.clazz; }
}

While the enum class compiles, I get compile errors if I try to use something like CLASS1.get(), saying that the types are incompatible.

Since I'm dealing with a framework, Class1, Class2, and Class3 must always extend ClassModelBase, and I can't change that or modify any of those classes. I'm stuck using these class object calls everywhere, and it's already been a problem with backwards compatibility being broken, so that's why I'm trying to group the class object constants in one place.

If the best thing I can do is the static class with static constants, I'll deal with it, and if there's a better way to do this than either static constants or an enum, I would be happy to hear it. Any advice would be welcome!

Thanks!

EDIT: A demonstration of what works and what doesn't. "example" and "createList" are just for demonstration; they don't actually matter for this.

// Works as class constant
List<Class1> objects = example.createList("param", Class1.class);

// Works as a static constant
List<Class1> objects = example.createList("param", ClassConstants.CLASS1);

// Compile error as enum
List<Class1> objects = example.create("param", ClassConstantsEnum.CLASS1.get());

EDIT2: The signature of createList:

public <T extends ClassModelBase> List<T> createList(String param, Class <T> type);

answers.title: Best approach using a list in Thymeleaf adding to a Bootstrap accordion by a nested value
answers.body:
So I figured it out with using a Map. For other beginners this is great to learn.

 @GetMapping("/rounds/{id}")
    public String roundsHome(@PathVariable(value = "id") Long id,
                             Model model) {
        List<Course> courses = courseService.getAllCourses();
        List<Round> rounds = userService.getUserById(id).getRounds();
        
        Map<Course, List<Round>> mapRoundsByCourse = rounds.stream().collect(Collectors.groupingBy(Round::getCourse));

        model.addAttribute("courses", courses);
        model.addAttribute("rounds", mapRoundsByCourse);
        return "/discgolf/round/rounds";
    }

Then I used the bottom answer here to render in my accordion.

answers.body_markdown:
Hmm; I don't know if you can extend built in types like in example. Ruby (my Java knowledge is not so deep enough).

However you can derive your own MyTextView from TextView. Then substitute all your TextView in layouts like this:

    <TextView android:id="@+id/TextView01" />

to

    <com.mydomain.mypackage.MyTextView android:id="@+id/TextView01" />

to automatically change type of all these fields.

Then you need to override all constructors
(especially `TextView(Context context, AttributeSet attrs)` ).

After that all layout inflaters (automatic or manual) will create this type with no fuss.

Then you can create/register context menu callbacks as you wish.
answers.title: Android add item to global context menu
answers.body:
Hmm; I don't know if you can extend built in types like in example. Ruby (my Java knowledge is not so deep enough).

However you can derive your own MyTextView from TextView. Then substitute all your TextView in layouts like this:

<TextView android:id="@+id/TextView01" />

to

<com.mydomain.mypackage.MyTextView android:id="@+id/TextView01" />

to automatically change type of all these fields.

Then you need to override all constructors (especially TextView(Context context, AttributeSet attrs) ).

After that all layout inflaters (automatic or manual) will create this type with no fuss.

Then you can create/register context menu callbacks as you wish.

answers.body_markdown:
This might be a little bit hacky, but you can trap the menu key at the application/activity level, check to see if your current active view is a text entry view, and then build and display your own custom popup menu.

It is possible, it's just a little tricky.

If you create/inflate a TextView, call setFocusable(false) on it, and then set it as the active view your **Activity** will still receive key events.
You will have to forward all those events (trackball, touch, key) to your View tree by hand. (Inside your "onKeyDown" function you'd have to call the appropriate "onKeyDown" method for the top level View)  You effectively have to trap the notion of 'focus' and dole it out to the correct view yourself.

While a little ugly, it may give you the desired results.

This would, however, only work in your own application.  Previous answers are correct about it being impossible across the entire phone.
answers.title: Android add item to global context menu
answers.body:
This might be a little bit hacky, but you can trap the menu key at the application/activity level, check to see if your current active view is a text entry view, and then build and display your own custom popup menu.

It is possible, it's just a little tricky.

If you create/inflate a TextView, call setFocusable(false) on it, and then set it as the active view your Activity will still receive key events. You will have to forward all those events (trackball, touch, key) to your View tree by hand. (Inside your "onKeyDown" function you'd have to call the appropriate "onKeyDown" method for the top level View) You effectively have to trap the notion of 'focus' and dole it out to the correct view yourself.

While a little ugly, it may give you the desired results.

This would, however, only work in your own application. Previous answers are correct about it being impossible across the entire phone.

answers.body_markdown:
Currently Android does not support this, you cannot override or hook functionality globally at the system level without the particular activity implementing an intent or activity that you expose.  Even in the case of publishing an intent it wouldn't matter unless the application running is a consumer... and all the base system applications and obviously all applications prior to yours would not be without updating the app to consume.

Basically as it stands, this is not possible.

What exactly are you trying to accomplish with this global context menu, some sort of global "Search For" or "Send To" functionality that runs through your application?

answers.title: Android add item to global context menu
answers.body:
Add intent-filter in your file android-manifest.xml:

<activity
   android:name=".ProcessTextActivity"
   android:label="@string/process_text_action_name">
  <intent-filter>
     <action android:name="android.intent.action.PROCESS_TEXT" />
     <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
     <data android:mimeType="text/plain" />
 </intent-filter>
</activity>

Get highlighted by user text in activity your app in method onCreate():

  @Override
protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
    super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
    setContentView(R.layout.process_text_main);
    CharSequence text = getIntent()
      .getCharSequenceExtra(Intent.EXTRA_PROCESS_TEXT);
    // process the text
}

More information in the article on medium.

answers.title: Add field from one event type to another event type
answers.body:
You could consider creating a pipeline that would be keyed by something that relates to the name that you care about (e.g. eid). This would ensure that all of the events flowing in that shared that identifier would be routed through the same stateful process function (i.e. KeyedProcessFunction).

Using a stateful function will allow you to store important state information for everything that shares that same eid (i.e. KeyedState) and you could perform some rudimentary enrichment as demonstrated below (with a simple example using some generic JsonObject but you could replace this with your own class):

// Function that accepts incoming keyed (strings) events 
// (JsonObject) and outputs enriched events (JsonObject)
class EventEnrichmentFunction: KeyedProcessFunction<String, JsonObject, JsonObject>() {

    // Define the state (mapping properties as key-value pairs of strings)
    private lateinit var state: MapState<String, String>

    override fun open(parameters: Configuration) {
        // Initialize the state (just a map of key-value string pairs)
        state = runtimeContext.getMapState(
            MapStateDescriptor("events", TypeInformation.of(String::class.java), TypeInformation.of(String::class.java))
        )
    }

    // Function that accepts an incoming event (JsonObject), 
    // enriches against state, and outputs events (JsonObject)
    override fun processElement(event: JsonObject, ctx: Context, collector: Collector<JsonObject>) {
        if (state.isEmpty) {
            // This is the first time we've seen an event 
            //with this id, so we need to add properties to keep
            // track of what we've seen
            state.put("name", event.name)
        }

        // Check for properties that you want to try and enrich
        if (!event.has("name") && state.containsKey("name")) {
            event.addProperty("name", state.get("name"))
        }

        // Return the enriched event
        collector.collect(event)
    }
}

Basically, any keyed stateful function will allow you to retain information based on a specific key (in this case the eid) so that future events sharing that same key can access the state of those preceding it, continuing to build the future matching events up over time:

if (state.isEmpty) {
    // This is the first time we've seen an event with this id, 
    // so we need to add properties to keep track of what we've seen
    state.put("name", event.name)
    state.put("another_property", event.another_property)
    state.put("yet_another_one", event.yet_another_one);

}

// TODO: Add checks and conditionally enrich events as needed from state

Which might looks something like this when defining your job itself:

events
   .keyBy { e -> e.get("eid") }
   .process(EventEnrichmentFunction())
   .sinkTo(...)

answers.body_markdown:
In the particular case of your a to b, b to c and such comparisons, you can get the desired result by giving the values array in reverse order. 

In a more general case, you could replace `'a'` with `'_b_'`, then `'b'` with `'_c_'`... And so on, and finally remove all the underscores. Of course, is your template text contains underscores, you can choose another character that you know won't be there, and use it instead.

answers.title: Replacing a set substrings in a string independently (parallel)
answers.body:
You better use a map and iterate over every character in template. This way you avoid multiple substitutions at the same index position.

String template = "abcd";
StringBuilder populatedTemplate = new StringBuilder();
HashMap<Character, Character> map = new HashMap<>();
map.put('a', 'b');
map.put('b', 'c');
for (int i = 0; i < template.length(); i++) {
    populatedTemplate.append(
            map.getOrDefault(template.charAt(i), template.charAt(i)));
}
System.out.println(populatedTemplate);

Some pro arguments of this solution compared to OPs posted solution.

  • avoid multiple substitutions at the same index position, replace in a first step a to b and in a second step b to c which would lead into an unexpected effective replacement of a to c
  • iterate only once over template
  • don't create for each replacement pair a new String object, as it would have been here p = p.replace(values[i], values[i+1]);

answers.title: Replacing a set substrings in a string independently (parallel)
answers.body:
Go with the solution using Map instead of String array to avoid getting ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. for instance you will get exceptions with this call using String array:

replaceMethod("abcd", "a","b","c")

Using Map:

     public static String replaceMethodMap(String template, Map<String, String> map) {
     String p = template;
     for (String key : map.keySet()) {
         p = p.replace(key, map.get(key));
     }

     return p;    
 }

items.title: Replacing a set substrings in a string independently (parallel)
items.body:
// The array of values is in the form { "var1", "val1", "var2", "val2",.. } 

 public static String replaceMethod(String template, String... values) {
            String p = template;
            for (int i = 0; i < values.length; i += 2) {
                p = p.replace(values[i], values[i+1]);
            }

            return populatedTemplate;    
        }

This method replaces a set of sub-strings with respectives values in a string. Ex:- string => abcd sub-string array of values ["a","b","c","d"] It means replace 'a' with 'b' and 'b' with 'c'.

So, now comes the issue.

1.My above implementation replaces 'a' with 'b' in first loop and then in second loop, it replaces 'b' with 'c' , making final string as "cccd". But I want the out as "bccd". Replacement in series uses the previous replaced string to work further. Is there a way to parallel replace all the sub-strings in a more efficient way.

2.How can I implement above method using Map, instead of array (second argument of above method)? Is Map better, or above implementation is fine ?

answers.body_markdown:
It should most probably look like this:
```
spring:
  cloud:
    azure:
      keyvault:
        secret:
          property-sources[0]:
            endpoint: ${uri}
            credential:
              client-id: ${clientId}
              client-secret: ${clientKey}
```

From the migration guide from 3.x.x to 4.x ([direct link](https://microsoft.github.io/spring-cloud-azure/4.2.0/reference/html/appendix.html#configuration-spring-cloud-azure-starter-keyvault-secrets)):

|Legacy properties|Modern properties|
|-----------------|-----------------|
|azure.keyvault.case-sensitive-keys|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].case-sensitive|
|azure.keyvault.certificate-password|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].credential.client-certificate-password|
|azure.keyvault.certificate-path|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].credential.client-certificate-path|
|azure.keyvault.client-id|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].credential.client-id|
|azure.keyvault.client-key|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].credential.client-secret|
|azure.keyvault.enabled|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.enabled and spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-source-enabled|
|azure.keyvault.refresh-interval|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].refresh-interval|
|azure.keyvault.secret-keys|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].secret-keys|
|azure.keyvault.tenant-id|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].profile.tenant-id|
|azure.keyvault.uri|spring.cloud.azure.keyvault.secret.property-sources[n].endpoint|

```
azure:
  keyvault:
    uri: ${uri}
    client-id: ${clientId}
    client-key: ${clientKey}
    token-acquire-timeout-seconds: 120

```
spring:
  cloud:
    azure:
      keyvault:
        secret:
          property-sources:
            uri: ${uri}
            client-id: ${clientId}
            client-key: ${clientKey}
            token-acquire-timeout-seconds: 120
```
What is the correct syntax for this azure keyvault version configuration??

}

Then inside main class I wish to fetch data from pets.csv into List<Pet>:

public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
    List<Pet> pets = readFile(Path.of("pets.csv"));
    pets.forEach(pet -> System.out.println(pet.name));
}

public static List<Pet> readFile(Path csvFile) throws IOException {
    try(MappingIterator<Pet> petIter = new CsvMapper()

        return petIter.readAll();

1
2
3

What am I doing wrong? :)

As you said you are using tomcat 5 and it support till servlet 2.5. But you are using servlet 3.0

<web-app xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee"

   xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee

There are two solutions: Upgrade your tomcat or use servlet 2.5

</web-app>

answers.body_markdown:
If you are using compiling output to `WEB-INF/classes` then it erases this folder each time you compile the application. To fix this you should change the folder used for compiler output.

If you ever seen this guide [How to Create a Dynamic Web Project in Eclipse][1] then you will realize that output folder is created outside the web content. 

[![][2]][2]  
<sub>(source: [eclipse.org](https://help.eclipse.org/kepler/topic/org.eclipse.stardust.docs.wst/html/wst-integration/images/set-build-path.png))</sub>  


This allows to store/clean compiled files during development. Finally when you deploy your application to the server the content should be copied to `WEB-INF/classes` automatically. 

Since class files are under `WEB-INF` folder they are not accessible from  outside the web and you can safely browse the content.


  [1]: https://help.eclipse.org/latest/topic/org.eclipse.wst.webtools.doc.user/topics/twcreprj.html?cp=86_0_1_1
 [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/gm4W5.png

answers.body_markdown:
> My question is why the java compiler needs to access the AccountUtility ?

Because.. you're using it. Right here: User.java, line 7:

> `AccountUtility.checkAccount(accountEntity);`

If it worked the way you apparently think it does, that `javac` does not need to know, then you could write `Doobedeedoodah.whatever()` and that should compile. If your cat then walked across your keyboard, that should also compile. Hey, if it isn't there at runtime, crash then, right?

Java does not work like that.

> If so why is no import for the interface needed ?

You appear to be suffering from a second misunderstanding. `import` is not like `import` in languages like javascript or python. __Import does absolutely nothing whatsoever__: It's a hint to the compiler, it does not result in _any_ bytecode at all. It is simply an alias, nothing more. `import com.foo.Bar;` means: "Whenever in this code, "Bar" appears anyplace a type is required, act as if the source code read "com.foo.Bar" instead".

It does not mean 'run this code'. This knife cuts both ways: `import`ing something doesn't mean that class will be initialized. And _not_ importing a thing doesn't mean that you can't use what you didn't import. Importing and class accessibility / initialization are __unrelated__.

You don't need to import it here because your code does not mention `AccountInterface` anywhere inside it. That doesn't mean `AccountInterface` is or isn't required at runtime or when compiling this code; that would depend on what the code does.

EDIT:

From a comment by OP:

> sorry indeed, I was referring to the AccountInterface bytecode, of course we need the AccountUtility :), can you re formulate your answer if you have time, I would appreciate it.

The parameter of the `checkAccount` method is `AccountInterface`. This means it's required for the _user_ module to make sense of this method. Yes, the method itself is accessible and is in the right module, but it is using a type in its _signature_ (the combination of its return type, the parameter types, and what it throws - signatures are _not_ about the code in the method itself), and anything used in a signature that you want to call needs to also be visible, accessible, and known, or you can't compile code that tries to call it. Even if you are passing a parameter that is of a type that _is_ accessible to your code and happens to be a subtype of the thing that is needed.

Further attempts to ask 'but why' on that pretty much boil down to 'cuz spec said so' / 'cuz spec writer wanted it to be so', and start veering out of range of what Stack Overflow is for.

answers.body_markdown:
Are you asking about true Java modules, with `module-info.java` files, or some construct of a build tool like Maven? 

If the former, both your account utility and account entity modules should express their dependencies on the account interface module with `requires transitive`, not simply `requires`. Then things that depend on the utility and entity modules would automatically get the dependency on the interface module (the interface module would be automatically "readable").

Even if these are not real Java modules, you should ensure that dependencies are listed in the correct scope. In Gradle, the utility and entity modules would list the interface module in their "api" configurations, rather than "implementation", because types from that dependency are part of their own public API. I assume there are parallels to this concept in Maven and other tools. By placing them in the right configuration, the tool can create appropriate classpaths for compile- and run-time.

Even if these are not real Java modules, you should ensure that dependencies are listed in the correct scope. items.title: Does java compiler needs access to Interface in the signature of the methods we are using?
items.body:
Let's say I have four modules, in a multi model set up project.

Instead of copying the gradle build, for convenience these are the dependencies among themselves, all with implementation scope.

user module -> account utility module
            -> account entity module
            
account utility module -> account interface module
account entity module -> account interface module
account interface module -> no dependency

Each module contains a single class, listing below:

User.java

import com.example.account.AccountEntity;
import com.example.util.AccountUtility;

public class User {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        AccountEntity accountEntity = new AccountEntity();
        AccountUtility.checkAccount(accountEntity);
    }
}

AccountUtility.java

package com.accountutility;


import com.accountinterface.AccountInterface;

public class AccountUtility {
    public static void checkAccount(AccountInterface account) {
        System.out.println(c);
    }
}

AccountInterface.java

package com.accountinterface;

public interface AccountInterface {
}

AccountEntity.java

package com.accountentity;

import com.accountinterface.AccountInterface;

public class AccountEntity implements AccountInterface {
}

Gradle is complaining that user module cannot access the account interface module. My question is why the java compiler needs to access the AccountInterface bytecode ?

Is it because the compiler needs to make sure that the class we are using is indeed an implementation of the interface ?

If so why is no import for the interface needed ?

Also can this be cumbersome to handle when using java module system ?

EDIT: So these are different modules or projects so you can think of it as the AccountUtility bytecode is already compiled and mentioned in the classpath when we try to compile User.java, the question is why the compiler still needs access to the bytecode of AccountInterface at compile time.

comments.body_markdown: Extra space is allocated to each component up to the maximum size of the component. This solution works for components like a JButton where the maximum size is the same as the preferred size. It won't work for a panel since its maximum size is Integer.MAX_VALUE.
comments.body: Extra space is allocated to each component up to the maximum size of the component. This solution works for components like a JButton where the maximum size is the same as the preferred size. It won't work for a panel since its maximum size is Integer.MAX_VALUE.

answers.body_markdown:
The solution here is to add a *glue* to the panel. In this case as the last component. A *glue* is described in Oracle docu as:

> Glue - Use this to specify where excess space in a layout should go. Think of it as a kind of elastic glue — stretchy and expandable, yet taking up no space unless you pull apart the components that it is sticking to. For example, by putting horizontal glue between two components in a left-to-right box, you make any extra space go between those components, instead of to the right of all the components.

Think of it as a kind of elastic glue — stretchy and expandable, yet taking up no space unless you pull apart the components that it is sticking to. answers.title: How can I get rid of spacing in Java BoxLayout?
answers.body:
When extra space is available in the panel, the BoxLayout will attempt to allocate that space to each component in the panel up to the maximum size of the component.

The maximum size of a panel is Integer.MAX_VALUE.

Override the getMaximumSize() method of your EntryPanel.

Something like:

@Override
public Dimension getMaximumSize()
{
    Dimension preferred = getPreferredSize();
    Dimension maximum = new Dimension(Integer.MAX_VALUE, preferred.getHeight());
 
    return maximum;
}

This will prevent extra space being allocated to the EntryPanel, so there will be no gap.

Another solution is to use a "wrapper" panel:

JPanel boxLayoutPanel = new JPanel(...)
JPanel wrapper = new JPanel( new BorderLayout() );
wrapper.add(boxLayoutPanel, BorderLayout.PAGE_START);
parentPanel.add(wrapper);

The PAGE_START area of the BorderLayout respects the height of components, so all components are displayed at their preferred heights and no gaps will appear between components.

items.title: How can I get rid of spacing in Java BoxLayout?
items.body:
I programmed following ListPanel:

with Javas BoxLayout:

public class ListPanel extends JPanel {
private ArrayList<EntryHolder> entries;

public ListPanel(){
    entries = new ArrayList<>();
    setLayout(new BoxLayout(this, BoxLayout.Y_AXIS));
    updatePanel();
}

public void updatePanel() {
    removeAll();

    synchronized (entries) {
        for (EntryHolder entryHolder : entries) {
            EntryPanel entryPanel = new EntryPanel(entryHolder);
            entryPanel.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(getPreferredSize().width, 50));
            add(entryPanel);
        }
    }
}

public void addEntry(EntryHolder entryHolder) {
    synchronized (entries) {
        entries.add(entryHolder);
    }
}

public void clearEntries() {
    synchronized (entries) {
        entries.clear();
        }
    }
}

The ListPanel is part of a JScrollPane which allows scrolling. An EntryPanel is a JPanel which consists of two other JPanels: one is always visible and the other one is only visible when the first one was clicked. The hidden one is setVisible(false) before I run the add() function on it. The EntryPanel uses a BorderLayout:

add(shownEntryPanel, BorderLayout.NORTH);
add(hiddenEntryPanel, BorderLayout.CENTER);

This approach works great for my scrollable list when there are enough entries to fill the whole ListPanel but as soon as there are fewer entries, white spacing occurs between EntryPanels:

I tried a lot of different layouts but I couldn't find one that does exactly what I want: position the panels from top to bottom without spaces but still having the ability to freely expand entries. I know that MigLayout is an option but I would like to NOT use any additional libraries.

How you do that depends on which build tool you're using or, if you're not using a build tool, then which IDE you're using. The database tab in IntelliJ IDEA is not related to your application. It's like a UI for accessing databases from the IDE. 

You need to add libraries to your app. You can do it [manually](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/library.html) (inside IntelliJ IDEA), or via the build tool (Maven/Gradle).

answers.title: Oracle JDBC (ojdbc) writes invalid doubles to oracle database
answers.body:
Check this example using SetFloatAndDoubleUseBinary.

import java.math.BigDecimal;
import java.sql.Connection;
import java.sql.DriverManager;
import java.sql.PreparedStatement;
import java.sql.ResultSet;
import java.sql.SQLException;
import java.sql.Statement;
import java.util.Properties;

public class DatabaseTest {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws SQLException {
        // System.out.println(200000000000000000000d);
        // System.out.println(Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY);
        // System.out.println(200000000000000000000d < Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY);
        // System.out.println(200000000000000000000d < Double.MAX_VALUE);
        // System.out.println(Double.MAX_VALUE);
        
        if (args.length < 3) {
            System.out.println("DatabaseTest url user password");
            System.exit(-1);
        }
        
        String url = args[0];
        String user = args[1];
        String password = args[2];

        testFLOAT(url, user, password);

        System.out.println();

        testFLOATSetFloatAndDoubleUseBinary(url, user, password);
    }

    private static void testFLOAT(String url, String user, String password) throws SQLException {
        System.out.println("--FLOAT datatype test");

        Properties p = new Properties();
        p.setProperty("user", user);
        p.setProperty("password", password);

        try (Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(url, p)) {
            conn.setTransactionIsolation(Connection.TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED);
            conn.setAutoCommit(false);

            try (Statement stmt = conn.createStatement()) {
                try {
                    stmt.execute("DROP TABLE test1");
                } catch (SQLException ex) {
                }
                stmt.execute("CREATE TABLE test1 (step NUMBER(10), num FLOAT DEFAULT 0 NOT NULL, remark VARCHAR2(100))");
            }

            try (PreparedStatement stmt = conn.prepareStatement("INSERT INTO test1 (step, num, remark) VALUES (?, ?, ?)")) {
                stmt.setInt(1, 1);
                stmt.setFloat(2, 200000000000000000000f);
                stmt.setString(3, "setFloat(_, 200000000000000000000f");
                stmt.executeUpdate();

                stmt.setInt(1, 2);
                stmt.setDouble(2, 200000000000000000000d);
                stmt.setString(3, "setDouble(_, 200000000000000000000f");
                stmt.executeUpdate();

                stmt.setInt(1, 3);
                stmt.setBigDecimal(2, BigDecimal.valueOf(2, -20));
                stmt.setString(3, "setBigDecimal(_, 200000000000000000000)");
                stmt.executeUpdate();
            }

            try (PreparedStatement stmt = conn.prepareStatement("SELECT num, DUMP(num, 16), remark FROM test1 ORDER BY step")) {
                stmt.execute();
                try (ResultSet rs = stmt.getResultSet()) {
                    while (rs.next()) {
                        System.out.println(rs.getString(3) + " : " + rs.getBigDecimal(1) + " dump: " + rs.getString(2));
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }

    private static void testFLOATSetFloatAndDoubleUseBinary(String url, String user, String password)
            throws SQLException {
        System.out.println("--FLOAT datatype test with SetFloatAndDoubleUseBinary=true");

        Properties p = new Properties();
        p.setProperty("user", user);
        p.setProperty("password", password);
        p.setProperty("SetFloatAndDoubleUseBinary", "true");

        try (Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(url, p)) {
            conn.setTransactionIsolation(Connection.TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED);
            conn.setAutoCommit(false);

            try (Statement stmt = conn.createStatement()) {
                try {
                    stmt.execute("DROP TABLE test2");
                } catch (SQLException ex) {
                }
                stmt.execute(
                        "CREATE TABLE test2 (step NUMBER(10), num FLOAT DEFAULT 0 NOT NULL, remark VARCHAR2(100))");
            }

            try (PreparedStatement stmt = conn
                    .prepareStatement("INSERT INTO test2 (step, num, remark) VALUES (?, ?, ?)")) {
                stmt.setInt(1, 1);
                stmt.setFloat(2,  200000000000000000000f);
                stmt.setString(3, "setFloat(_, 200000000000000000000f");
                stmt.executeUpdate();

                stmt.setInt(1, 2);
                stmt.setDouble(2, 200000000000000000000d);
                stmt.setString(3, "setDouble(_, 200000000000000000000f");
                stmt.executeUpdate();

                stmt.setInt(1, 3);
                stmt.setBigDecimal(2, BigDecimal.valueOf(2, -20));
                stmt.setString(3, "setBigDecimal(_, 200000000000000000000)");
                stmt.executeUpdate();
            }

            try (PreparedStatement stmt = conn
                    .prepareStatement("SELECT num, DUMP(num, 16), remark FROM test2 ORDER BY step")) {
                stmt.execute();
                try (ResultSet rs = stmt.getResultSet()) {
                    while (rs.next()) {
                        System.out.println(rs.getString(3) + " : " + rs.getBigDecimal(1) + " dump: " + rs.getString(2));
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Moreover malformed numbers stored by JDBC driver can not be transferred using expdp/impdp.

Upon import impdp gives following output:

Processing object type SCHEMA_EXPORT/PRE_SCHEMA/PROCACT_SCHEMA
Processing object type SCHEMA_EXPORT/TABLE/TABLE
Processing object type SCHEMA_EXPORT/TABLE/TABLE_DATA
ORA-02374: conversion error loading table "USER"."TEST1"
ORA-01722: invalid number

ORA-02372: data for row: NUM : ''


ORA-02374: conversion error loading table "USER"."TEST1"
ORA-01722: invalid number

ORA-02372: data for row: NUM : ''

Summary. Avoid using setFloat and setDouble in you code(even with other databases). Anyways Oracle internally stores numberical types in form of digits - like BigDecimal does. Convert your number into BidDecimal format on your side and pass these digits to database driver.

comments.body_markdown: It's not a bug. It is known behavior that doesn't always do what you expect. What is happening is that is Oracle Database JDBC `setFloat` and `setDouble` send numeric values to the Oracle Database as Oracle SQL `NUMBER` type, not `BINARY_FLOAT` or `BINARY_DOUBLE`. The flag described by @ibre5041 tells the driver to transport `floats` and `doubles` as `BINARY_FLOAT` and `BINARY_DOUBLE`. Another more targeted way to accomplish the same thing is to use `OraclePreparedStatement.setBinaryFloat` and `OraclePreparedStatement.setBinaryDouble`. These methods send the values as binary types not `NUMBER`
comments.body: It's not a bug. It is known behavior that doesn't always do what you expect. What is happening is that is Oracle Database JDBC setFloat and setDouble send numeric values to the Oracle Database as Oracle SQL NUMBER type, not BINARY_FLOAT or BINARY_DOUBLE. The flag described by @ibre5041 tells the driver to transport floats and doubles as BINARY_FLOAT and BINARY_DOUBLE. Another more targeted way to accomplish the same thing is to use OraclePreparedStatement.setBinaryFloat and OraclePreparedStatement.setBinaryDouble. These methods send the values as binary types not NUMBER

items.title: Oracle JDBC (ojdbc) writes invalid doubles to oracle database
items.body:
I are experiencing a strange problem writing a certain double value to an Oracle database via the OJDBC drivers.

If I write the exact double value 7.00E+20 into a field of type FLOAT(n), BINARY_FLOAT, BINARY_DOUBLE or NUMBER(38,10) by OJDBC, the value cannot be retrieved in Oracle tools like SQL Plus or SQL Developer. However, similar values such as 7.00E+19, 7,000001E+20 and 7.00E+21 do not cause any problems.

The special value can be retrieved with another JDBC call, or if I use fake arithmetics like SELECT (strange_field + 1 – 1) FROM mytable in SQL Plus. If I try to read strange_field directly, the value is displayed as nothing or (null) in SQL Plus and SQL Developer.

Example table:

CREATE TABLE my_table(id VARCHAR(20), strange_field FLOAT(126));
INSERT INTO my_table (id, strange_field) VALUES ('Value by SQL Plus', 7.00E+20);

Sample groovy script which shows the effect (the issue occurs also in Java or applications like SQuirreL SQL):

import groovy.sql.*

println "Start SqlTest.groovy"

// Oracle
driver = "oracle.jdbc.OracleDriver"
url = "jdbc:oracle:thin:@//localhost:1521/xe"
username = "test"
password = "test"

id = 'Value by OJDBC'
double value = 7.00E+20 //error!
//float value = 7.00E+20 //value is stored correctly!

sql = Sql.newInstance(url, username, password, driver)
try {
 sql.execute 'INSERT INTO my_table (id, strange_field) VALUES (?, ?)', id, value
 sql.eachRow('SELECT id, strange_field FROM my_table'){row -> println row}
} finally {
  sql.close()
}

println "Finished SqlTest.groovy"

SQL Plus:

SELECT * FROM my_table WHERE strange_field IS NULL don't returns the affected row.

If strange_field is of type BINARY_FLOAT or BINARY_DOUBLE, the value 7E+20 is displayed as NaN in SQL Plus and cannot be retrieved again by JDBC or the arithmetic trick in SQL Plus.

I have already tested with ojdbc7 and ojdbc10 drivers, different JDKs (8 and 17), and Oracle databases (12.2, 18c and 21c). The issue occurs in every constellation.

I also suspect that the error might occur with other float values.

Has anyone already experienced a similar problem, can reproduce it and/or has a idea for a workaround?

answers.body_markdown:
Your `ClientHandler` constructor already tries to read from the socket. If the client doesn't immediately sends a line (including line break!), the socket will keep waiting.

Move `this.username=br.readLine();` and everything after it to the `run` method, before the loop. That way all reading will be done in another thread.

comments.body_markdown: I am aware of how to manually create a wiki within the GitHub interface. I would like to do it remotely.
comments.body: I am aware of how to manually create a wiki within the GitHub interface. I would like to do it remotely.

answers.body_markdown:
You can use the Wiki link from the top action bar from within the repo. Within the Wiki area, you can create pages desired right from the web by clicking the New Page button. There are also Edit and Preview buttons on the web page for viewing before you save the Wiki document.

To add to this, I did not realize you were trying to script your changes. The wiki exists in a separate, but parallel repo to the code repo and you do not have to clone the code repo to get the wiki repo (although you do need to clone the wiki repo). You can access the xyz.git repo's wiki using xyz.wiki.git. On the Wiki page (which you already know about), and of course, you can get the URL by clicking on the Git Access button at the top.

If you really can't clone the wiki repos, Git offers only a total of 4 protocols as specified in the [Git Documentation][1]. Here is a blog post that talks about [8 ways to share your git repository][2], which may give you some clues to other ways to do what you want to do.


  [1]: http://git-scm.com/book/ch4-1.html
  [2]: http://www.jedi.be/blog/2009/05/06/8-ways-to-share-your-git-repository/

answers.title: How can I remotely edit/create a wiki for a GitHub Repo?
answers.body:
As of 2023-03, creating wiki (git) repositories on GitHub programmatically is not officially supported.

GitHub's official REST API (Version: 2022-11-28) supports the creation of repositories. However, if you try to create a "wiki" for some code repository, named say "REPOSITORY_NAME" (meaning, you want to create the git repository "REPOSITORY_NAME.wiki"), will end up with an error like:

{
  "message": "Repository creation failed.",
  "errors": [
    {
      "resource": "Repository",
      "code": "custom",
      "field": "name",
      "message": "name cannot end in .wiki"
    }
  ],
  "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#create-a-repository-for-the-authenticated-user"
}
gh: Repository creation failed. (HTTP 422)

AFAIK then, your only chance is to create the wiki repository using the non-documented call from the GitHub website:

  • On your browser, if you want to create a wiki manually, you will see that this is a call to a GET method with the URL pattern: https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/REPOSITORY_NAME/wiki/_new. This redirects you to a new site with the title "Create new page".
  • Inspecting the button Save page (id: gollum-editor-submit) shows you that the underlying routine to create a wiki git repository is a POST method with the pattern https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/REPOSITORY_NAME/wiki (the web HTML includes a hidden input with the name authenticity_token; again this is not documented and is likely to change). Calling this method with the right inputs (and I guess some needed headers) will create your desired new git repository.
  • Finally, to later push your git repository from scratch, you will need to force it: git push -f origin.

answers.body_markdown:
The consumer listener enables the native Kafka metrics, the `spring_kafka_listener` metrics are controlled by the `micrometerEnabled` container property, which is true by default.

https://docs.spring.io/spring-kafka/docs/current/reference/html/#micrometer

The metrics will only be captured if Micrometer is on the class path.

If you can't figure it out, provide an [MCRE](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example) so we can see what is wrong.

@Configuration
@EnableKafka
public class KafkaConsumerConfig {

    @Autowired
    private KafkaProperties kafkaProperties;

    @Bean
    public Map<String, Object> consumerConfigs() {
        Map<String, Object> props = new HashMap<>(kafkaProperties.buildConsumerProperties());
        props.put(ConsumerConfig.KEY_DESERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, StringDeserializer.class);
        props.put(ConsumerConfig.VALUE_DESERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, StringDeserializer.class);
        props.put(ConsumerConfig.GROUP_ID_CONFIG, kafkaProperties.getConsumer().getGroupId());
        return props;
    }


    @Bean
    public ConsumerFactory<String, String> consumerFactory() {
        final StringDeserializer jsonDeserializer = new StringDeserializer();
        ConsumerFactory<String,String> cf = new DefaultKafkaConsumerFactory<>(
            kafkaProperties.buildConsumerProperties(),
            new StringDeserializer(), jsonDeserializer
        );
        //I tried to add it but it didn't give any result
        cf.addListener(new MicrometerConsumerListener<>(new SimpleMeterRegistry()));//
        return cf;

    }

    @Bean
    public ConcurrentKafkaListenerContainerFactory<String, String> kafkaListenerContainerFactory() {
        ConcurrentKafkaListenerContainerFactory<String, String> factory =
            new ConcurrentKafkaListenerContainerFactory<>();
        factory.setConsumerFactory(consumerFactory());
        factory.setBatchListener(false);

        return factory;
    }

    @Bean

        return new DefaultKafkaHeaderMapper();
    }

answers.title: How can I get the autoincremented id when I insert a record in a table via jdbctemplate
answers.body:
Check the Chapter 11. Data access using JDBC reference. You can use jdbcTemplate.update as:

EDIT Added imports as asked

import java.sql.Connection;
import java.sql.PreparedStatement;
import java.sql.SQLException;

import org.springframework.jdbc.core.JdbcTemplate;
import org.springframework.jdbc.core.PreparedStatementCreator;
import org.springframework.jdbc.support.GeneratedKeyHolder;
import org.springframework.jdbc.support.KeyHolder;

following is the code usage:

final String INSERT_SQL = "insert into my_test (name) values(?)";
final String name = "Rob";
KeyHolder keyHolder = new GeneratedKeyHolder();
jdbcTemplate.update(
    new PreparedStatementCreator() {
        public PreparedStatement createPreparedStatement(Connection connection) throws SQLException {
            PreparedStatement ps =
                connection.prepareStatement(INSERT_SQL, new String[] {"id"});
            ps.setString(1, name);
            return ps;
        }
    },
    keyHolder);
// keyHolder.getKey() now contains the generated key

and the code snippet:

    final String INSERT_SQL = "INSERT INTO [table]\n"
            + " ([column_1]\n"
            + " ,[column_2])\n"
            + " VALUES\n" +
            " (?, ?)";

    Connection connection = jdbcTemplate.getDataSource().getConnection();
    PreparedStatement preparedStatement = connection.prepareStatement(INSERT_INVOICE_SQL, Statement.RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS);
    preparedStatement.setString(1, "test 1");
    preparedStatement.setString(2, "test 2");

    preparedStatement.executeUpdate();
    ResultSet keys = preparedStatement.getGeneratedKeys();

    if (keys.next()) {
        Integer generatedId = keys.getInt(1); //id returned after insert execution
    }

answers.body_markdown:
JdbcTemplate is at the core of Spring. Another option is to use [SimpleJdbcInsert][1].

    SimpleJdbcInsert simpleJdbcInsert = new SimpleJdbcInsert(jdbcTemplate);
    simpleJdbcInsert
        .withTableName("TABLENAME")
        .usingGeneratedKeyColumns("ID");
    SqlParameterSource params = new MapSqlParameterSource()
        .addValue("COL1", model.getCol1())
        .addValue("COL2", model.getCol2());
    Number number = simpleJdbcInsert.executeAndReturnKey(params);	

You can still @Autowire jdbcTemplate. To me, this is more convenient than working with jdbcTemplate.update() method and KeyHolder to get the actual id.

Example code snippet is tested with [Apache Derby][2] and should work with the usual databases.

Use of [Spring JPA][3] is another option - if ORM is for you.

  [1]: https://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/jdbc/core/simple/SimpleJdbcInsert.html
  [2]: https://db.apache.org/derby/
  [3]: https://projects.spring.io/spring-data-jpa/
answers.title: How can I get the autoincremented id when I insert a record in a table via jdbctemplate
answers.body:
JdbcTemplate is at the core of Spring. Another option is to use SimpleJdbcInsert.

SimpleJdbcInsert simpleJdbcInsert = new SimpleJdbcInsert(jdbcTemplate);
simpleJdbcInsert
    .withTableName("TABLENAME")
    .usingGeneratedKeyColumns("ID");
SqlParameterSource params = new MapSqlParameterSource()
    .addValue("COL1", model.getCol1())
    .addValue("COL2", model.getCol2());
Number number = simpleJdbcInsert.executeAndReturnKey(params);

You can still @Autowire jdbcTemplate. To me, this is more convenient than working with jdbcTemplate.update() method and KeyHolder to get the actual id.

Example code snippet is tested with Apache Derby and should work with the usual databases.

Use of Spring JPA is another option - if ORM is for you.

answers.title: How can I get the autoincremented id when I insert a record in a table via jdbctemplate
answers.body:
@Component
public class PersonDao {

    private final JdbcTemplate jdbcTemplate;

    @Autowired
    public PersonDao(JdbcTemplate jdbcTemplate) {
        this.jdbcTemplate = jdbcTemplate;
    }

    public List<Person> index() {
        return jdbcTemplate.query("SELECT * FROM person", new BeanPropertyRowMapper<>(Person.class));
    }

    public Person show(int id){
        return jdbcTemplate.query("SELECT * FROM person WHERE id=?", new Object[]{id}, new BeanPropertyRowMapper<>(Person.class))
                .stream().findAny().orElse(null);
    }

    public void save(Person person){
        jdbcTemplate.update("INSERT INTO person (name, age, email) VALUES (?, ?, ?)", person.getName(), person.getAge(), person.getEmail());
    }

    public void edit(Integer id, Person person) {
        jdbcTemplate.update("UPDATE person SET name = ?, age = ?, email = ? WHERE id = ?", person.getName(), person.getAge(), person.getEmail(), id);
    }

    public void delete(Integer id) {
        jdbcTemplate.update("DELETE FROM person WHERE id = ?", id);
    }
}

answers.title: How to add leading zeros and specify decimal figures at the same time with printf
answers.body:
Java: use the Formatter class. Examples of expected usage:

StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
// Send all output to the Appendable object sb
Formatter formatter = new Formatter(sb, Locale.US);

// Explicit argument indices may be used to re-order output.
formatter.format("%4$2s %3$2s %2$2s %1$2s", "a", "b", "c", "d")
// -> " d  c  b  a"

// Optional locale as the first argument can be used to get
// locale-specific formatting of numbers.  The precision and width can be
// given to round and align the value.
formatter.format(Locale.FRANCE, "e = %+10.4f", Math.E);
// -> "e =    +2,7183"

// The '(' numeric flag may be used to format negative numbers with
// parentheses rather than a minus sign.  Group separators are
// automatically inserted.
formatter.format("Amount gained or lost since last statement: $ %(,.2f",
                balanceDelta);
// -> "Amount gained or lost since last statement: $ (6,217.58)"

items.title: Weblogic 12.2.1.4.0 use Jackson Fasterxml instead of Codehaus Jackson
items.body:
Our applications will be deployed on Weblogic Servers Version 12.2.1.4.0. We removed the usage of codehaus jackson completely from our code and want to use jackson fasterxml in version 2.13.2 instead. During the test we´ve faced some issues with that.

It seems that Jersey switches randomly between codehaus jackson (which still exists in weblogic libraries) and the fasterxml libraries which we deploy with our applications.

To solve the problem we added this to the weblogic.xml of the application without success:

<container-descriptor>
    <prefer-application-packages>
        <package-name>com.fasterxml.jackson.*</package-name>
    </prefer-application-packages>
</container-descriptor>

With each deployment we see different output. We tested it by adding a bean with LocalDate to a Rest Service response.

Sometimes we see

{"year":2023,"month":"MARCH","dayOfMonth":9,"monthValue":3,"era":"CE","dayOfWeek":"THURSDAY","dayOfYear":68,"leapYear":false,"chronology":{"id":"ISO","calendarType":"iso8601"}}}

and sometimes we see

{"localDate":"2023-03-09"}

as the result. With unit tests we checked the output of codehaus/fasterxml ObjectMapper when converting to text so we guess it switches randomly between codehaus and fasterxml version.

What we deploy with the application:

  • jackson-databind
  • jackson-datatype-jsr310
  • jackson-core
  • jackson-annotations
  • jackson-jaxrs-json-provider

We disable Moxy by adding this properties to the application:

props.put("jersey.config.server.disableMoxyJson", Boolean.TRUE);

For JSR310 in addition we add an ContextResolver that registers the JavaTimeModule with the fasterxml ObjectMapper.

In the web.xml of the application in addition we set the provider for jersey by following context param:

<context-param>
    <param-name>jersey.config.server.provider.classnames</param-name>
    <param-value>com.fasterxml.jackson.jaxrs.json.JacksonJaxbJsonProvider</param-value>
</context-param>

Could you please let me know in case something is wrong with this configuration? In fact we want that Jersey always uses the new Fasterxml implementation instead of the old codehaus version.

answers.body_markdown:
A `protected` method is a method that can be invoked: 

 - Either inside the class `Frog` that declares it
 - Or inside the instance source code of any subclass of `Frog`
 - Or ultimately from within the same package

In your specific case, you are in neither of these cases.
The tricky part may be that you are writing your call inside the source code of `Tadpole`, that is a subclass of `Frog` (so you may say hey, I'm in the case two). 

But actually it's not like that. 
You are not invoking the method from an instance method of the class `Tadpole`, rather you are in a `static` context (a `main` method), where you are creating an instance of `Frog f`, and you're trying to access the method from that instance `f`. You may be anywhere else, and it would be the same thing. 

If the method `ribbit()` was private, you wouldn't have been suprised that you couldn't do `f.ribbit()`. But the same goes for `protected`, if you think the same way.

I have Tadpole class that extends Frog, as follows:

1: package animal;
2: public class Frog {
3:   protected void ribbit() { }
4:   void jump() { }
5: }

1: package other;
2: import animal.*;
3: public class Tadpole extends Frog {
4:   public static void main(String[] args) {
5:     Tadpole t = new Tadpole();
6:     t.ribbit();
7:     t.jump(); // doesn't compile due to default access
8:     Frog f = new Tadpole();
9:     f.ribbit(); // doesn't compile 
10:    f.jump(); // doesn't compile due to default access
11: } }

Lines 7 and 10 do not compile due to the package-private access of the jump() method.

I understand that upcasting of Tadpole class into Frog class on line 8 will allow the parent instance member (the ribbit method) to be accessed from the subclass since the method is not overwritten.

Protected methods should be able to be accessed from a subclass whether it's in the same package or different package right? If so, why doesn't line 9 compile?

answers.body_markdown:
You can access the dependencies by calling `project.getArtifacts()`. From its javadoc:

> All dependencies that this project has, including transitive ones. Contents are lazily populated, so depending on what phases have run dependencies in some scopes won't be included. eg. if only compile phase has run, dependencies with scope test won't be included.

You can use attributes on `@Mojo` to control the dependencies that are available. Specifically, you need to set both `requiresDependencyResolution` and `requiresDependencyCollection` to `ResolutionScope.TEST`.

You can use attributes on @Mojo to control the dependencies that are available. Specifically, you need to set both requiresDependencyResolution and requiresDependencyCollection to ResolutionScope.TEST.

items.title: Maven plugin: get access to the "same classloader" as when running tests?
items.body:
I'm trying to develop a Maven plugin that looks for certain classes and generates specific documentation for them. I've built a POC as a unit test. I'm trying to convert that now to a Maven plugin.

The test code has access to the classes of the project + the classes of any dependency. I'd like to have that "same classloader" (or a classloader with the same access) available in my Maven plugin.

Is this possible?

Getting access to the project classes

Creating a classloader that contains the classes of the project is doable:

@Mojo(name = "tao-generator", defaultPhase = LifecyclePhase.INSTALL)
public class TaoGeneratorMojo extends AbstractMojo {

    @Parameter(defaultValue = "${project}", required = true, readonly = true)
    MavenProject project;

    ...

    @SneakyThrows
    private ClassLoader getClassLoader(MavenProject project) {
        List<URL> runtimeUrls = new ArrayList<>();
        List<String> runtimeClasspathElements = project.getRuntimeClasspathElements();
        for (int i = 0; i < runtimeClasspathElements.size(); i++) {
            String element = runtimeClasspathElements.get(i);
            runtimeUrls.add(new File(element).toURI().toURL());
        }

        URL[] array = new URL[runtimeUrls.size()];
        array = runtimeUrls.toArray(array);

        return new URLClassLoader(array,
                Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader());
    }

Getting access to the dependencies' classes

I haven't figured out how to create a classloader that has access to the dependencies classes. Can I use a similar technique, starting from MavenProject project?

Another angle: loading classes from a fat Spring Boot jar

I've also tried to load the classes directly from the generated fat Spring Boot jar. That doesn't work with a simple URLClassLoader, since that classloader isn't able to load classes from nested jars. Maybe this could be the starting point of another angle to make this work?

answers.body_markdown:
There was a recent change to the order; see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-retry/pull/335 and https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-retry/pull/333#pullrequestreview-1330977780

It will be available in 2.0.1 (currently in 2.0.1-SNAPSHOT).
answers.title: What is the interaction between the @Transactional and @Retryable annotations in spring?
answers.body:
There was a recent change to the order; see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-retry/pull/335 and https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-retry/pull/333#pullrequestreview-1330977780

It will be available in 2.0.1 (currently in 2.0.1-SNAPSHOT).

items.body_markdown:
According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59582135/does-annotations-order-matter the order shouldn't matter, however for these two it seems that the order does matter. 

If the transaction occurs within the retry, then the transaction could roll back, throw an exception, then spring will retry it. However if the retry occurs within the transaction, there won't be a rollback between each retry as the retry will catch the exception and go again.

There could be also situations like the database details changing between retries.
items.title: What is the interaction between the @Transactional and @Retryable annotations in spring?
items.body:
According to Does annotations order matter? the order shouldn't matter, however for these two it seems that the order does matter.

If the transaction occurs within the retry, then the transaction could roll back, throw an exception, then spring will retry it. However if the retry occurs within the transaction, there won't be a rollback between each retry as the retry will catch the exception and go again.

There could be also situations like the database details changing between retries.

Well, I don't know if I understood your question, but if you are trying to read the children of all the nodes without specifying them, you can try to do something like the code below: (I didn't test it, I just changed your sample)

    myRef = myfire.getReference("Users");
    myRef.addValueEventListener(new ValueEventListener() {

        @Override
        public void onDataChange(@NonNull DataSnapshot dataSnapshot) {

            for (DataSnapshot keySnap : dataSnapshot.getChildren()) {
                for (DataSnapshot schoolSnap : keySnap.getChildren()) {
                    for (DataSnapshot rollSnap : schoolSnap.getChildren()) {
                        String mRollSnap = rollSnap.getKey();

                        String name = mRollSnap.child("basic").child("fb01name").getValue().toString();
                        String number = (String) mRollSnap.child("basic").child("fb04roll").getValue().toString();
                        if(name == null){
                            Toast.makeText(getApplicationContext(),"Invalid",Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
                        }
                        basic model = new basic(name,number);
                        tvName.setText(name);
                        tvRoll.setText(number);

                    }
                }
            }
        }
        @Override
        public void onCancelled(@NonNull DatabaseError error) { }
    });
